text: on March eighth Malaysia Airlines flight
MH 370 took up from Kuala Lumpur and
vanished and route to Beijing for the
next two weeks all three us network
newscasts led with the missing flight
every single night they devoted 91
minutes to it on their first week of
coverage and 92 minutes on week two
while the world was searching for the
plane Russia was annexing Crimea but
that story got only 55 minutes of news
coverage in that same time period
critics say the focus on the fight comes
at the expense of other news stories
leads to idle speculation not
informative coverage not that the
American public seems to mind according
to a pew research survey almost half of
americans said that the news provided
the right amount of missing flight
coverage and only a third of Americans
found the network's coverage to be
excessive and the ratings showed no sign
of flight fatigue that's a big deal
considering that in 2013 cable news
audiences declined by nearly all
measures according to Pew the average
number of primetime viewers of the big
three cable channels dropped to their
lowest levels since 2007 and hey
anything that gets the US News to focus
on an international story can't be all
bad in 2013 1671 minutes of nightly
network news coverage were devoted to
overseas stories that may sound like a
lot but it's only eleven percent of the
total yearly news output and that's half
of what it was in the 1980s the news
organizations can't count on sensational
stories to keep their numbers up forever
instead they may want to look at how
they get the story right now thirty-six
percent of u.s. adults watch online
videos and almost fifty percent of
teenagers do and it's not just cat
videos
news makes up half of the videos
Americans now watch online
